key_points: WHO designated the B.1.1.529 variant, named Omicron, as a variant of concern on 26 November 2021.
Omicron has several mutations that may affect its transmissibility and the severity of the disease it causes.
It is unclear if Omicron is more transmissible or causes more severe disease than other variants, including Delta.
Preliminary evidence suggests an increased risk of reinfection with Omicron compared to other variants of concern.
Current vaccines remain critical to reducing severe disease and death, including against Delta.
PCR tests continue to detect Omicron, and studies are ongoing to assess the variant's impact on other types of tests and current treatments.
WHO is coordinating global research efforts to better understand Omicron's characteristics and impact.
WHO recommends countries enhance surveillance, share data, report cases, and perform investigations to understand Omicron better.
Countries should implement effective public health measures and address inequities in access to COVID-19 vaccines and treatments.
Individuals should maintain preventive measures such as physical distancing, wearing masks, and getting vaccinated.
